subject: sync bmc time from ipmb host
commitMessage:
sync bmc time from ipmb host

This script runs at startup as systemd service.
It checks if the bmc time is in sync from NTP server.
otherwise it reads the host time via ipmb interface
and updates as bmc time.

This change was tested and verified in yosemitev2 and tiogapass
platforms.

Signed-off-by: Naveen Moses <naveen.mosess@hcl.com>
Change-Id: I8c937c16415b2dd05d05155facadc0bed797db07

Change has been successfully merged by Patrick Williams
Suggest to put the machine name in the commit message.
Can we use const variable in the loop ?
word wrapping to be max of 80. Seeing in few other lines.
Both Wants and After needed here ?

it will not affect the  expected behaviour of service as wants is much like optional requirement
for the mentioned service
Add a comment to explain what you are doing here.
Please name executables with lower-dasherized (or lower-kebab-case if you prefer that name).  Also, drop the ".sh".
Why do we need to explicitly set the PATH?

I would suggest a more unique name here like:

HOST_INSTANCES_SED_REPLACEMENT_VALUE
What is the purpose of this line?

Why the echo?  I would probably just make this whole function as:

check_NTP_status()
{
    timedatectl show --property=NTPSynchronized --value
}

Let the consumer do something like:

NTP_STATUS="$(check_NTP_status)"

Rather than spreading knowledge of variables between functions.
Can we open a task to figure out how to make this common?  Ideally the code here would not need to know any different between "multi-host (ie. BIC)" and "single-host (ie. ME)" access paths.

Does shellcheck pass on this?  I suspect it has opinions about storing $? into a variable rather than simply doing:

if busctl ...; then break; else continue; fi

Can we avoid these kinds of echo calls?

What did we do with the results (line 50) vs logging an error in this case?  Should we call 'logger' when we want to report problems?

Please do not use hidden variables between functions like this.  Save the result of the function call:

output=$(get_multi_host_datetime $ipmb_addr)
The get_multi_host_datetime function has retry option if the ipmb command fails so for this purpose the intermediate variable is needed.

I don't understand that leap of reasoning.  Capture the results of the retry and forward them?

I think part of your problem is that you're mixing logging information and fucntional information.  Maybe use stderr for user-aware logging?

Type=Simple + RemainAfterExit=yes is wrong.

I think you want Type=oneshot.
Per https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/anti-patterns.md#incorrect-placement-of-executables-in-sbin-usrsbin-or-bin-usrbin , I think this belongs in /usr/libexec?
File is still named .sh and with CamelCase instead of kebab-case.
Still see a lot of magic numbers with no documentation.
You're still using global variables as a cross-function communication.  Please don't do this.
Once again, please drop ".sh" from the file name.
